p.span: In response to the most recent information we have available at this point, and in alignment with other Kings County School Districts, Kings River-Hardwick School District is closing schools beginning Monday, March 16th, through Monday, May 4th, 2020 (updated 2020-03-27). This is a difficult decision, but necessary, as we try to slow the spread of the virus. Just to be clear, we do not have any confirmed cases of COVID-19 in Kings County as of March 17th, 2020. KRH serves students at all levels of need and we have a responsibility to not only educate, but protect our children. We are hopeful that these closures remain short term and do not continue to be extended, but that guidance comes from the department of health and is somewhat out of our hands. Along with the closure of school and classes, any and all athletic contests and practices, academic team practices, field trips, events, activities, and school functions are cancelled or postponed through May 4th, 2020 (updated 2020-03-27). Those restrictions may be extended beyond that date even if school resumes that day or prior. The safety of our students is our top priority. Again, this is not an easy decision and not one we take lightly.
Please continue to refer to our website at kingsriverhardwick.com for updates and details. Thank you for your understanding and support during this time of national crisis.

p.strong: Letter from the Kings River-Hardwick Superintendent:

div.p: Dear Kings River-Hardwick Parents and Community,

On Wednesday, April 1, 2020, Governor Gavin Newsom held a press conference and announced that all California school facilities will remain closed to students through the end of the 2019-2020 school year, in response to increased COVID-19 cases throughout the state. The extension of school closures reaffirms the Governor’s previous statement, and his intention to continue “stay at home” orders to protect public health.

As safety continues to be one of our top priorities, Kings River-Hardwick School District will be adhering to the Governor’s recommendations and extending the closure of our school facilities through the remainder of the 2019-2020 school year. Although our campus will remain closed, I assure you, school will continue to be in session via distance learning through June 5th.

As I shared in my letter dated, March 27, 2020, Kings River-Hardwick School will continue to provide distance learning via independent study packets, online learning, and in some instances a blend of both delivery methods. Our teachers are actively reaching out to you and your children via Bloomz, email, and Google Classroom. If you do not have access to any of these communication methods at this time, please contact your child’s teacher.

If your child is in TK-3rd Grade, you will receive a printed independent study packet in the mail within the coming days. Our final distribution of iPads and independent study packets will take place this evening for our 4th grade students. All instruction for 5th-8th grade students will be delivered via Google Classroom on student iPads and/or other preferred technological devices, beginning Tuesday, April 14th. Please ensure your student takes advantage of the recommended learning opportunities their teachers are working diligently to provide.
In addition, we will continue to provide meals for students once per week following Spring Break, through the remainder of the school year. Reminder messages will be sent via Bloomz each week.

In the coming days we will share updates to specifically address 8th Grade Graduation, History Day, etc. We understand these are important milestones for our graduates, and plan to do our best to creatively find alternatives that will enable us to honor these special KRH rites of passage, even if we must wait until the fall.

Thank you for your continued support of our KRH family during these unprecedented times. Please let us know if there is any way we may assist you. We look forward to opening our campus and resuming face-to-face classroom instruction on Thursday, August 13th, 2020.
Wishing you all continued health and happiness,
Cathlene Anderson

p.strong: Letter from the Kings River-Hardwick Superintendent:

div.p: Hello Kings River-Hardwick Parents and Community,

For the past two weeks, Kings River-Hardwick School has been closed due to the COVID-19 outbreak. In our initial closure letter, we shared with you our desire to reopen our school following spring break, on April 14th. Unfortunately, due to the continued severity of the COVID-19 outbreak, and the advisement of current federal, state, and local health officials, Kings River-Hardwick School District will be extending our current facility closure through Friday, May 1st, 2020, and are hopeful classroom-based instruction will resume on Monday, May 4th. This is a very difficult decision, but necessary, as we try to flatten the curve, and slow the spread of the virus. This continued closure is intended to protect the health of our students and staff members.

As our facility closure continues, our focus will be on continuing to provide meals and educational opportunities through distance learning for our students. Thank you to those of you who have picked up independent study packets from the school during lunch distribution times and those who have been accessing the online learning opportunities that were posted to our website on Tuesday, March 17th. If you have not accessed this online information or picked up a printed packet, I would encourage you to do so. Printed packets will still be available on Monday, March 30th from 10:30 a.m. – 12:00 p.m. during our lunch distribution.

Following spring break, Kings River-Hardwick School will continue to provide distance learning via independent study packets, online learning, and in some instances a blend of both delivery methods. Your child’s teacher will be in contact with you late next week to begin the process of acquainting you with the distance learning model that will be utilized in your child’s grade level through May 1st.

Lunches will continue to be provided weekly throughout the closure, with the exception of the week of spring break. Lunch distribution will be held at KRH as well as the Hardwick Fire Station from 10:30 a.m. – 12:00 p.m. on the following dates:

ul.li: Monday, March 30th
Tuesday, April 14th
Monday, April 20th
Monday, April 27th

div.p: In closing, I would like to share with you an excerpt from a blog post entitled, “Keep Calm and Parent On”

p.em: “Let me remind you of your ultimate and sacred responsibility as a parent – being there for your kids, as you’ve done every day. These are scary times and we don’t know what will really happen tomorrow. But for today, you’re all together. Hold them, reassure them, and play with them. We’ll get through this – and they’ll remember how their Moms and Dads were there for them each step of the way. You got this.”

div.p: Thank you for your continued support of our KRH family. Please let us know if there is any way we may assist you during this time. We will all get through this together.
Cathlene Anderson

p.strong: Letter from the Superintendents of Kings County:

div.p: Kings County Community:

Earlier this month, Kings County school district superintendents, with the support of their boards of trustees and in consultation with the local public health department, made the decision to temporarily close our schools due to the COVID-19 outbreak. Since then, we have remained in constant contact with one another, monitoring local, state and national announcements that affect our schools. During the closures, we have focused on providing students with meals, educational enrichment opportunities, and planning for distance learning. We initially planned to resume classroom instruction in April, promising to continually evaluate the situation.

As leaders, we are charged with doing everything we can to respond to the declared state and national emergency. We heed the governor’s recent “shelter in place” order and the sustained guidance to practice social distancing.

Dr. Milton Teske, Health Officer for the Kings County Department of Public Health, advises that our community needs to continue to focus on containment, and an important part of that effort is keeping school facilities closed. Looking ahead, we can identify criteria that would need to be met before school resumes normally. These include the lifting of the statewide “shelter in place” order and the removal of the guidelines for social distancing and restrictions on social gathering.

Given these current circumstances, we have come to a collective decision that the safety of our families and our community outweigh all other considerations. We recognize the need to extend the closure of our physical sites until May 1, 2020. Our focus will be on providing meals to our students and education through distance learning. We will continue to evaluate the ever-changing circumstances, remaining hopeful classroom based instruction will resume on May 4, 2020.

Parents should contact their local district offices or school sites for specific information related to their schools. Please follow the direction and guidance from your school administrators regarding measures they are taking for the benefit of all.
Thank you for your support and understanding in our efforts to keep our communities safe.
Sincerely,
The Superintendents of Kings County:

Kings County Fire Station #2 Hardwick ( 14680 Excelsior Avenue, Hanford, CA 93230 ) @ 10:30am – 12:00pm, on Mondays (or first day of the week).
